On Wed, 2004-06-30 at 16:16, Morten Grum wrote:
> Is there a good way of comparing/tracking consecutive junit result sets?
> Perhaps with a xslt style sheet for junit-report?

The best situation to be in is to have all the tests pass.  If you don't
have all the tests passing, and you can't get them to pass in a
relatively short timeframe, then you might want to ask yourself what the
value of having the failing tests is.

(I've been on a team where some of the tests stayed broken for many
weeks. I don't know why we kept those tests; it's not as though they
added any confidence that the system worked properly.  At least, they
didn't provide me with any of that sort of confidence; they mostly
provided me with confidence that the tests weren't an accurate
reflection of the state of the system.)

If all the tests pass, the only value to compare from one run to the
next is "how many tests are there" -- and that's not something that you
really need a stylesheet to manage.

Did that answer help at all?
 
-- 
Brett Neumeier <random@...>
